posts.text: @judy What is roadmap to move from MysQL 5.8 to MySQL 8 for the MySQL tile on TAS?

replies.text: We don’t have plans to have MySQL on TAS support MySQL 8. MySQL on k8s will support MySQL 8 though. /cc @mpurna
That is great!  How far away is MySQL on k8s?
We’re aiming for an internal alpha by Q3 this year — the full roadmap is here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/149HLcO77z57wz7s7fJziZiDpoo6MLcfNNHur_hZxGv8/edit
Kind of a silly Q perhaps but is there any up-to-date equivalent of the above document?

Well, everything's pretty much moved to Confluence now.Tanzu SQL: https://confluence.eng.vmware.com/display/TSQL/Tanzu+SQL+Product+Roadmaps
Tanzu Data Services high-level: https://confluence.eng.vmware.com/display/TD/Tanzu+Data+Services+Quarterly+Results
Thank you @marco_n!
Anything in particular I can help with?
Well, I was trying to get a better idea of the broader effort that MySQL for K8s is part of. I guess I need to learn about Tanzu Data Services.

posts.text: Following the discussion started by Nate around the availability of Tanzu SQL as an open source project, I’d like to know our agenda. A customer is currently evaluating the PostgreSQL operator in a POC: they asked us if this Tanzu SQL will ever be open sourced or not. They’re already using crunchy-data and kubedb (not the paid version), competition is RH and Rancher. Thanks for your help. /cc @cmiquel

replies.text: Currently, the only thing that is not open sourced is the operator itself. While I'm not actively part of the discussion I know there have been conversations taking place. I think what would be helpful would be a compelling reason to open source it or not. What I have heard thus far is several asks about if we are or aren't but no reasoning behind the ask.Could you tell us more about the ask from the customer? What are they looking for and what is their reasoning?

The customer is a governmental agency, They are fond of open source, but they struggle with scaling these solutions. The VMware brand is strong with this customer - they already run thousands of VM with vSphere. Now they want to deploy K8s at scale, and they need to make a choice. Since most of the products in the Tanzu family are open sourced, it would make sense to have Tanzu SQL available as an open source product. Especially when you have RH and Rancher sending a lot of FUD about the open source commitment from VMware.

Let's ignore this quote for a moment.WRT the open source nature of TQL (speaking about Postgres here because that is what I know)The product consists of an operator which orchestrates the server, a HA monitor and a backup solution. All 3 of those are open source, there isn't a vendor lock in from the perspective of the components, additionally in the server there are a number of extensions that are all open source.We are active contributors to the Postgres server as well as the HA solution. All of that is being done with the communities involved.  Effectively we are engaging with Open source communities and effectively packaging those products to enable user outcomes.Again, the operator/packaging is currently the only thing not open sourced.
Coud you please share a link to the open source components? Any idea if/when the full package will be open sourced?

posts.text:
Gartner MQ for cloud databases.  Interestings that jumped out after skimming:
*Alibaba moved into the leaders quadrant
*"Contributors to Gartner’s Peer Insights platform report that the move to Azure was often more expensive than their on-premises deployments had been."
*Oracle is introducing a managed Postgres service in 2021
*IBM appears to remain in the leaders quadrant based on inertia
*Why isn't VMware represented?  Because our AR group will not support us unless we can be reasonably assured of being in the leaders quadrant.  However, we've done extensive briefings of Gartners DMBS analysts and will accelerate once we get the new data strategy worked out with data services on Tanzu Editions

*Why isn't VMware represented? Because our AR group will not support us unless we can be reasonably assured of being in the leaders quadrant. However, we've done extensive briefings of Gartners DMBS analysts and will accelerate once we get the new data strategy worked out with data services on Tanzu Editions.
I think this is also because we don't have a SaaS service, which is now a requirement even to appear on the quadrant.
*IBM appears to remain in the leaders quadrant based on inertia, and because they implemented a powerful  service on IBM Cloud, which in some cases outperforms what RDS/Azure SQL implemented
Does Tanzu SQL include both Postgres for K8s and MySQL for VMs?

And Postgres RPMs.
And in the future, MySQL on K8s. (edited)
Tanzu SQL Roadmaps cascade: https://confluence.eng.vmware.com/display/TSQL/Tanzu+SQL+Product+Roadmaps

@here Please give a shout out to Judy Wang for releasing MySQL 2.10.0. https://tanzu.vmware.com/content/blog/vmware-tanzu-sql-relational-database-on-demand-mysql-developer-productivity-enterprise-readiness

https://www.crunchydata.com/case-study/sas/

replies.text: Postgres for Kubernetes is GA v1.0.0, but we probably need to ship a patch for TKG.MySQL is Beta, but they’re working on GAing soon.

posts.text: @channel Hey Everyone, VMware Postgres 13.2.0 is live on Tanzu Net! I wanted to give a special shout out to the hard work of @vmware-postgres-team for their efforts getting automation in place for the future, as well as trudging through the OSM process. Special thanks to @Kris and @Rachel for ushering us through the Release Process. I also wanted to thank @Lena Hunter for getting us squared away on the documentation front. Congrats everyone for getting this release out the door! Please see the Release Notes for all of the packaged extensions and information about this release.

replies.text: Congrats! Curious, does this include containers and deployment by the Operator??
This is our release that is packaged as an RPM.
The goal is to achieve this status (single publication in all formats and channels), we aren't far from that. Hope next update we will be on that model.

One minor packaging difference for this release: the zipfile containing the JDBC driver will now untar into a folder, instead of just to a jar file. We have a VMware legal requirement to include the OSL file in the download so it now behaves like the other zip files in our packaging.The other files’ structure has not changed. (edited)
The docs should not need an update, as the structure was not called out specifically. https://postgres.docs.pivotal.io/13-2/installing.html#jdbc

posts.text: Hi, I enabled "enable secure service instance credentials" in TAS mysql for VM tile, when binding the mysql service instance to application, it can correctly refer to the credhub url, however when I create service key, the password is in clear text, is it correct as designed?

replies.text: Yes, the service key is for the developer who doesn't have access to TAS credhub to find the credential

Just to be clear; service keys are still stored in CredHub. It's just that Cloud Foundry is rendering them for you when you ask for the information, as that's the purpose of service keys.It's the same way that Cloud Foundry (by default) interpolates credhub URLs when deploying an app, so that the app, also, sees the credentials in cleartext.But in both cases, the credentials are stored in a secure manner.
OK, got it, Thanks a lot!

posts.text:
Hello - Could you share what is the DNS approach for the current tanzu mysql tile (multi-site) setup?
cc @bwebster (edited)

replies.text: What are you interested in regarding the DNS approach precisely?  Service discovery?  How database instances connect to each other?  How the apps connect to the database?At a high-level, the Tanzu MySQL tile’s architecture is described here:https://docs.pivotal.io/p-mysql/2-10/about-multi-site.htmlEssentially, in that architecture an app in each site connects “locally” to a mysql instance.   That mysql instance may be a primary or a read-replica.   If it’s a read-replica we proxy to the connection to the primary.We expect a user to implement a global / DNS load balancer in front of their applications in this case.If you have specific questions, I can try to answer those more precisely.

@here postgres for k8s docs refers to jetstacks/cert-manager, any way to roll our operator without it?

replies.text: No, sorry. (edited)
cert-manager installs the certificate used to perform webhook validations, so that portion is required.

helm install cert-manager … gives me
Error: rendered manifests contain a resource that already exists. Unable to continue with install: CustomResourceDefinition "certificaterequests.cert-manager.io" in namespace "" exists and cannot be imported into the current release: invalid ownership metadata; annotation validation error: missing key "meta.helm.sh/release-name": must be set to "cert-manager"; annotation validation error: missing key "meta.helm.sh/release-namespace": must be set to "cert-manager"
It looks like cert manager is already installed, but in a different namespace cert-manager
I’ve deleted that namespace and all resources performing the above again with same outcome
there are cluster-wide resources that remain.
like the custom resource definition.
to uninstall cert-manager, you’d need to use helm to perform the uninstall
at this point helm might be a little confused at the current state of the world.
what you can do is run helm template --namespace=cert-manager on the cert-manager chart and then pipe the rendered templates into kubectl delete (edited)
error deleting for all resources
Error from server (NotFound): error when deleting "STDIN": clusterroles.rbac.authorization.k8s.io "RELEASE-NAME-cert-manager-cainjector" not found

hi all, question about using Minio with pgBackRest - is it possible to leverage it without TLS?

replies.text: Yes, there is a field in the backup location secret called verifyTLS that you can set to “false”.
Seems like a bad idea. Is there a reason for the ask?
Self-signed certificate?
Ideally you'd be able to trust that cert as the root, and still use TLS with full verification.
This is just for a demo...and i did try using verifyTLS but it didn't work for me

(Deployed Minio via a. helm chart which does not use TLS by default, requires a few extra steps to enable TLS on the Minio server which I dont have the banwidth for yet...so right now the minio endpoint only supports http, not https) (edited)
Oh, pgbackrest always uses TLS, but allows you to skip verification. (edited)
Got it..so I must use a TLS endpoint. Thanks for confirming!

posts.text: I have a Postgres on K8s customer who is trying to add commands to the Dockerfile that we ship and then rebuild the Docker image. They are running into an error during the build based on this new DockerFile. Is this something that customers should be doing? If not, how should we proceed? (edited)

replies.text: Wow, we should not be shipping the Dockerfile. If we are, that’s an oversight.
Actually they mentioned using dedockify to reverse engineer the image into a Dockerfile.
They could possibly use our image as a base image, and then build more on top. I strongly recommend against it, and like others have mentioned, I don’t think we would want to support their instances.

posts.text: It is explicitly not supported
Who is the customer?
Yeah, I’m curious what they are trying to achieve and why
Prime Therapeutics these are the commands they are trying to add to it:

replies.text: We have added (or are actively adding) specific language to our documentation to say we do not support folks modifying our operator/pod code (in this way mentioned) because it is not something that we can plan for. I think we can offer something to the customer in finding out what the outcome they are looking for is exactly and adding that to the roadmap.
Sure I can find that out and see if it's something we can improve.
@Nick @khuangdata we have added this note to Postgres 1.2 and backporting to 1.1 and 1.0
Oh cool thanks for the note

Why the need for ssh? First, putting on a static external port limits number of instances per worker to 1.  Second, if it is too gain access to database logs, there are alternatives we should consider packing into our image such as sending to syslog server or an "instance" database with ability to query logs
@eckhardtr wrt accessing database logs, it would be very handy to include log_fdw in our image
Above would ease the need for access into the running image
kubectl logs <some pod name> should give you all the logs including database logs. We ensure this happens already. (edited)
@pjemish that includes access to instance database logs?  I see example in docs for operator
Yes it does

posts.text: Hi, can Tanzu SQL-PG supported in all public cloud? Azure?

replies.text: Are you referring to the bare metal product or the for-k8s product?

We haven’t fulling tested for-k8s in all clouds, but it works on GCS, so is likely to work on others.The bare-metal product can be installed wherever you like, as long as they are using RHEL7 or Centos7. That product is a bit more advanced, as you might imagine.

posts.text: Hi, I see Tanzu Postgresql supports full/ differential backup & restore of Postgres, are there plans to support backup & restore for specific databases or tables?

replies.text: Are you referring to the K8s product?Assuming yes the answer to tis isn’t easy. You can somewhat accomplish tis today using pg_dump which is a basically a data dump and then restore only the data you are interested in. This isn’t really considered a normal or desired backup technique in Postgres because it only contains the data from that exact point in time and can’t really be updated.Another way to somewhat accomplish this is through logical replication of only the tables or DBs of interest. Usually logical replication is used for near real time replication of a subset of data.
Could I ask specifically what you’re trying to do?

Hi @eckhardtr thanks for the response, yes I am looking for the k8s tanzu postgresql product.
The requirement here is to backup few databases/ tables and not the entire Postgres.
curiosity question, does Tanzu Postgres backup & restore works using logical replication?
Why, Is there a space limitation or do you expect restore performance
No, We use physical replication.
Logical replication doesn’t support DDL, DML, which makes it difficult to count on
physical replication ==> pg_basebackup + WAL
Yes for the space constraints, and in our case, few databases/ tables can be restored directly using the application that is using it.
this answers, as you are using pg_basebackup this always takes the whole cluster backup as compared to pg_dump
correct.

posts.text: @interrupt - I was trying to install Tanzu MySQL for Kubernetes 1.2.0 and ran into the following issues. I’m unable to proceed further.
MariaDB I think
So I undertand that Percona and Oracle follow the same numbering
but MariaDB uses another numbering (10.x today)
Correct - Percona releases lag by the Oracle releases by approx. 3 months, but they follow the same numbering.
can we make a correlation between MariaDB version and MySQL versions?
because now I understand that the customer document is imprecise
I will need to go back to them to clarify
they require MariaDB or MySQL version 10.4.x or newer
As alluded earlier, we do not support MariaDB. (edited)
but that does not make sense
as MariaDB and MySQL are now different products

@macedol Based on the headers in https://mariadb.com/kb/en/compatibility-differences/, MariaDB 10.4 is the first MariaDB version which is comaprable with MySQL 8. Which is a big deal because MySQL got a lot of features between 5.7 and 8.0, almost enough to be worth considering So the most recent 8.0, as shipped with DMS would be a good start. Do read the caveats on that page though, the projects have developed in different directions, most of it's just details but one or two items may matter for a particular application.
tks @alturner
so MariaDB didn’t really took off and mySQL is a more advanced/reliable option?
I don't think it's that simple.
MariaDB put a lot of effort into function and procedure support, for instance, which MySQL did not.
There are a lot of stories that MariaDB corporation is very difficult to work with as well.
AFAIK, that's part of how we ended up with a MySQL product and not a MariaDB one.
product wise they are pretty similar still then
Changing topics
replication multisite
what is the model? sync or async?
Are you referring to DMS?
or MySQL in general
In Genereal and on DMS
Do we allow customers to install mySQL on VMs customers provide or  only DMS or k8s offerigns?

replies.text: DMS provisioned VMs, K8s provisioned nodes, or PCF tile VMs via Bosh (edited)

If this is not a K8s play then I don’t really have an answer for you. They can just use the OSS bits but that assumes they require no expertise when developing the platform and it implies they won’t hit any bugs or other issues during development.Maybe that’s true.Is the work they are doing net new?  Either way could you share a bit more about the app?

So this is more Rabbit related then Postgres at this time (however both are in the proposal mix). The app is E911. They are selected to develop modern E911 system for multiple states. Their financials (how they get paid would be based on how they rollout the product). So it is possible, they don't get paid(then it is an investment on their part for the services as well as product license costs) until the app goes live. @jhoffman Is this correct assumption? Hence they the reluctance to buy the product now in 2022.
that is all correct.

Hi there,Dutch STA-OB Driebergen have opened support case 301628 for an issue with a Postgres 1.5.0 / TKGi 1.13.1 cluster.They’re hitting the "Error: failed to create containerd container: create ftainer failed validation: containers.Labels: label key and value greater than maximum size (4096 bytes), key: io.deplab" issue described in https://vmware.slack.com/archives/C01GC0YFE75/p1642038978021400They have confirmed that the runtime is containerd://1.5.7' so we’ve confirmed that their issue is as described in the Slack post above - kubectl get nodes -o wide output for their cluster is below:
Hi there! Just have a question regarding how cores are counted for Postgres instances in K8s; should the core count include the instance + monitor pods, or just the instance pod?

replies.text: We don’t really have a good answer. Currently we are asking customers to estimate their usage and then pay that amount.Included in the “their usage” is the monitor and the data pods
Right now I’m more concerned about getting people using the product and providing feedback.
got it, thanks!...so it's just the monitor and data (aka instance) pods that are used for estimates, correct?
Yes
@tseufert ^
The only other resources used are the Operator pod and the S3 bucket.  I don’t care about either of them
got it! thanks!

posts.text: @channel - VMWare Tanzu SQL with MySQL for Kubernetes 1.3.0 is live on Tanzu Net! Congratulations and thanks to the following teams for the efforts involved in making this happen-
Hi Team, please check out the service bindings feature that the Tanzu SQL team shipped with the latest Tanzu SQL with MySQL for Kubernetes v1.3.0. Short demo video below:

@channel – Data Management for VMware Tanzu 1.2.0 is live on Tanzu Net! Congratulations and thanks to the following teams for the efforts involved in making this happen-
·      Documentation
·      Engineering
·      Product Design
·      Technical Architecture

·      Enhanced Log Management
·      Flexibility in Managing Environments

Hi Team - Our customer Lloyd's Bank was performing some failover testing with their K8s Postgres pre-prod testing environment.   They attempted to stop the secondary (postgres-1), but found that it would automatically restart quickly.  Their solution to this was to rename the postgresql.conf on the postgres-1 pod.  Now, 'postgres-1' is crashing and is unable to start.  Lloyd's Bank wishes to know if there is any way they can recover from this scenario without recreating the pods. Adding details to a thread.

replies.text: @alturner ^^^^What is Llyods doing?

After they renamed postgresql.conf 4/5 containers were running for several hours.  Now it's in this state:
kubectl get pods -n ns-kcl-postgres
Not intended to be snarky legit curious because I didn’t thing they were using our operator

That’s how the system is designed. The operator attempts to keep the system as specified - highly available with a primary and a secondary. If they want to scale down to one node they can, but they need to do it through the operator.

In this state, they might want to scale down, delete the persistent volume associated with pod-1, and then scale back up again.They could also spin up a pod that also mounts that volume and put the files back into place.
It also sounds like they / we need to understand what they are trying to accomplish or we are going to end up in this or a similar mess consistently
@Aaron if you’d like a more in-depth tour of our product, throw some time on my calendar and we can go over it. I’d like to help you be prepared for these kinds of scenarios.

posts.text: @Aaron @khuangdata there were 2 tickets opened up by Penske.

I assumed OS
They have like the high level steps in the 2nd case ( AKA 306385) .  I can ask them for the more detailed plan if they have one.
Hi All - Has anyone been in touch with Penske on this outside of the case?  If not, I will tell them that we're still discussing internally.
Oh god yes
We do need Jira created for the 2 tickets

posts.text:
Hi Team, I was having a discussion with @ssapra for the vulnerabilities, after upgrading to Tanzu Postgres 1.6.0 there are few that are being raised as critical when I am running it through appcheck https://appcheck.eng.vmware.com/#/product/376834/analysis
@ssapra informed me that there will be release 1.6.1 this week in which all vulnerabilities but golang-runtime-1.17.6 (CVE-2022-23806) will not be fixed, as GoLang has recently released 1.18
(1) is it possible to have a Tanzu Postgres release 1.6.2 build with GoLang 1.18,
(2) if first option is not possible can I build the source on my own with GoLang and contribute it back to release 1.6.2?cc: @vmware-postgres-pms

replies.text: Would the latest Golang 1.17 be acceptable? You should be receiving that in the release of 1.6.1.
1.17.8 is the latest and should be fully patched, as far as I know.

yes I see this thread https://groups.google.com/g/golang-announce/c/SUsQn0aSgPQ
and https://github.com/golang/go/issues/50974
looks like >=1.17.7 should have the patch. Thanks! (edited)

@Vishrant Gupta Currently the SLO is that we patch only critical vulnerabilities w/in 48 hours.  The 1.6.1 release is happening to fix a customer issue with NetApp and pgbackrest so we are patching the OS while we ship.I’m not sure what the normal SLO is for VMware but it would be a change of process for us to ship patches for high CVEs.@Mike @Nick @alvaro @jinalis

posts.text: Hi there! Cross-posting this from the #mysql-for-tas channel in case anyone here can assist - thanks in advance https://vmware.slack.com/archives/C0NFRTZ36/p1650024590071439

Hi All - Is it supported to change the storage class from the operator yaml (postgres.yaml)?  I believe I see this being done here https://vmware.slack.com/archives/C0199H5UBB9/p1642589675028400.   Customer is running operator 1.5 (edited)

replies.text: @vmware-postgres-team FYI
What is the issue they are facing?
It is not supported.
The storage class can only be set during instance creation.
Otherwise we’d have to migrate the data from the storage using the old storage class to a new storage class.
If this is something you’d like to do, maybe restoring to a new instance using the new storage class might work.

No issues now. An SP customer mentioned a question for us as we were disengaging earlier.  They noticed that when they delete a persistentvolumeclaim, that the persistentvolume was also deleted.They were curious if there is some way to override this at the operator level so that the PVs would all be retained even if the PVC is deleted.(sorry my original question was meant to contain a link which I've edited in now.  That link seems to be unrelated at this point)

posts.text: I’d love to chat with them if they are at a point in the sale cycle where that can easily happen

replies.text: I’d also like to dig into what they want with Quotas.
assuming it is the same customer

Back to the original question (quotas): @oawofolu Are you familiar with OPA/Gatekeeper? It’s perhaps a steep learning curve, but it can be used for really fine-grained and arbitrary policies. I recall that the gp4k team put together an example of using it for some specific customer ask that didn’t make sense to put in the product.

@dsharp Thanks! I've looked into it briefly in the past; yep, would be even more complex than ResourceQuotas/LimitRanges (the customer was looking for a simple-enough solution - they're new to K8s). I could look into it some more, though.
If they're using TMC then those policies and quotas can probably be managed more easily/consistently across clusters. + it has a UI haha
@oawofolu we are writing up the backup TLS story.  Once I have a more clear understanding of the workflow I want to validate that it meets what it needed. My current understanding:
@eckhardtr Yes, and another note is that an approach which skips the TLS verification would be acceptable (similar to the -insecure flag with curl/current implementation in Postgres4K8s).

posts.text: Hi Guys

Hi there, quick question about the latest PG4K8s release (just got around to upgrading to 1.8) - it might be my environment and I don't have any hard numbers yet, but it takes minutes to deploy a new cluster (as opposed to seconds with 1.7) so just wanted to check if this was a known issue before starting to work on troubleshooting the environment? Thanks in advance...! (edited)

replies.text: I have not heard of this as a known issue. Depending upon where your images are coming from Tanzu net or local, and your network speed I have seen variances.
I did copy the images to my own registry; all environment settings are similar to what I used for 1.7. hmm

let us know what you find
cc #vmware-postgres-on-kubernetes @interrupt
^ @Ria Mahoney @dsharp @swatin

I tried the two versions out for both single and HA instance on minikube with images already loaded in the local registry. For me, it was approx. the same amount of time: Single node instance taking approx. 30 secs and HA instance taking around 64 seconds to transition from Created to Running state. What k8s cluster are you running the operator on @oawofolu? I can try on a similar env perhaps.

posts.text: (edited)

replies.text: Everything you said is correct. The monitor is an important element. A fully healthy HA cluster has 3 components, primary, mirror, monitor. If any 2 exist the cluster can still be fully read write.
With K8s the configuration cannot be manipulated at this time
If you're interested in the bare metal setup it can get far more complicated
Thanks!

replies.text: Hi @gspiegelberg, this is not an issue. That message generally appears because pg_autoctl hasn’t been configured (DR is configured) and a pg_autoctl command was executed (edited)

DR not working
It may be that your expectation of what should happen and what actually happens is different.
pgbouncer being used?
I had the same reaction when using it for the first time.
No pgbouncer.
DR failover did not work so expectations not met
Can you explain what you mean by DR failover did not work? Where in the process did they encounter an issue? Maybe the customer should open an issue so we can have a look (edited)

k8s cluster 1 with primary archiving
k8s cluster 2 with DR warm standby set up
k8s cluster 2 DR copy signaled to become primary
Logs suggest it did as archive-push commands present but at some point PG stopped
Customer had to bring k8s cluster 1 back up
